column2: Send the 7a Divisione CC. NN. "Cirene" in Africa.

The Blackshirts division ‘Cirene’ was created in April 1936 to be sent in Abyssinia. It was the seventh division sized unit raised by the MSVN to conduct military operations. The division was above 14.000 men strength, including 8 regiments of ''Camicie Nere' and various support units. Its commander war general Guido Scandolara, a mountain fighter and highly decorated officier of the Great War. Finally, the division was kept in reserve in Libya in the event of a conflict with United Kingdom in Egypt.
Milizia Volontaria per la Sicurezza Nazionale (MVSN).

MVSN or "Camicie Nere" was created on in February 1923. It was the military organised police corps of the fascist State, based upon the former "Squadre d'Azione", the paramilitary force that brought Mussolini to power. Its first commander was Italo Balbo (1924) and rapidly the force was put under the direct control of Benito Mussolini (1926-1943).
The MVSN rose up to 111 "Legioni" (Regiment sized units), using 17 to 50 years old men and was divided in various and specialized branches:
- "Milizia Ordinaria", including "Milizia Coloniale", "Milizia Confinaria" (Border Guards) and "Milizia Universitaria"
- "Milizia Forestale" (Forest Guards)
- "Milizia Stradale" (Urban Police)
- "Milizia Ferroviaria" (protecting railway stations)
- "Milizia Portularia" (protecting harbours)

In 1930 was created the "Milizia per la Difesa Controaerea" (DICat), protecting essential cities of Italy with AA guns. Another branch from the DICat the "Milizia Maritima" (MilMart) was created in 1935 and put in charge of the coastal defense, the Regio Esercito being relieved of this task. From 1934 to the war, the MSVN also raised combat divisions that fought in  Balkans, Russia, Libya, Tunisia and Italy…
Comando Truppe di Zara.

Comando Truppe del Presidio di Zara was created on Janary, 1st 1936. This garrison force was set up to defend the city and port of Zara, an italian enclave in the Yougoslavian territory.

The originality of this unit was to merge various types of italian troops: Guardia alla Frontiera, Milizia Voluntaria per la Sicurezza Nazionale, and three different forces from the Regio Esercito – Carabinieri Reali, Bersaglieri and armored troops, including L 5/21 tanks and Lanzia 1ZM armored cars.
At the outbreak of hostilities with Yougoslavia in april 1942, the division enter in combat actions, occupying cities of Zaravecchia, Nona, Obrovazzo, Bencovazzo, Scardona and finally Tenin were it made junction with the 2a Armata , especially the 133rd Armored Division "Littorio", capturing 2,200 prisonners. In 1942, this garrison force was reorganised into and occupation force division: 158a Divisione Fanteria "Zara".
Form the 158a Divisione Fanteria "Zara".

On September 1st 1942, the Zara garrison force was renamed 158a Divisione Fanteria "Zara" and set up as an occupation division for the Italian province of Dalmatia. Its iniatial commander was Carlo Viale, replaced later by Emilio Giglioli. This division is also known to have committed various attrocities and war crimes against Yougoslavian partisans and civilians.
65a Divisione Fanteria "Granatieri di Savoia".

65a Divisione Fanteria "Granatieri di Savoia" was set up in Ethiopia on October 12th, 1936 and garrisoned in Addis Abeba. Its first commander was general Luigi Perego. The division was assigned to anti-guerilla operations in Ethiopia, before being involved in combat actions against allied troops, particulary in the defensive battle of Cheren. It was finally destroyed on April 20th 1941.
Ordinamento Baistrocchi.

Federico Baistrocchi (1871-1947) was appointed as Chief of the Army General Staff in October 1st 1934. Highly decorated artillery officer of the Great War, Baistrocchi supported the fascist movement in Naples and assured Mussolini his troops won't intervene against him. He was elected three times (in 1924, 1929 and 1934) as Deputy for the PNF. Supporter of the fascist power, he made a rapid military ascension, becoming in July 1933 Undersecretary of State for the Ministry of War, held by Mussolini himself, before becoming Chief of Staff of the Royal Army from October 1st, 1934 to October 7th, 1936. 
Baistrocchi issued on November 14th, 1933 the so-called "Ordinamento Baistrocchi" (Baistrocchi's reform), a deep reform of the Italian Army. This reform focused on modernisation of weapons, motorisation and mechanization of troops, dividing forces between standing and defensive ones like the Guardia alla Frontiera. Baistrocchi organized the logistical warfare in Ethiopia and favorise the constitution of MVSN divisions for the war.

Baistrocchi's program, perhaps too ambitious, was only partially implemented.
Appoint Alberto Pariani as Chief of General Staff.

In october 1936, germanophile Alberto Pariani (1876-1955) replaced Federico Baistrocchi as Chief of the Army General Staff and Undersecretary of War, after Baistrocchi's "promotion", motivated by a conflict with Marshall Pietro Badoglio and different political views in the involvment of Italian troops in the Spanish Civil War. Pariani fought WW1 and occupied various fonctions as military attaché in Albania, general commander of the 18a Divisione 'Brennero' and Deputy Chief of General Staff from 1934 to 1936. He was defending the concept of "Guerra di rapido corso" (war of mobility) like other generals from different countires: Basil Liddell-Hart, Heinz Guderian, Mikhaïl Toukhatchevky or Charles de Gaulle... Pariani led a deep reform of the Italian Army, based on the field experiences in Ethiopia and Spain.
Ordinamento Pariani.

By Decreto n° 2095 of December 22nd, 1938 (called "Ordinamento Pariani") all infantry divisions of the Regio Esercito were set on a new standard: one of the three infantry regiment was removed and replaced by one 81 mm mortar battalion, one At-company and one anti-aircraft battery. These binary divisions, thought to be more able to act rapidly were tested during the greats manœuvers of summer 1937 and 1938. Mussolini was not convincted by this reform but finally accept Pariani's proposal, which was increasing the total number of divisions of the Army from 31 to 51 Infantry Divisions along the new semi-motorized, motorized and armored divisions created. To compensate the lack of power, each division was assigned a battalion and then a brigade of MVSN Blackshirts.\n\n§RNote for player: this event will lock the technology that allows increasing brigade size.§B
Pietro Badoglio's warning.

Alberto Pariani was suddenly removed as Undersercretary of War on November 13th, 1939 by Mussolini for not being equal to the challenge. He was replaced by Rodolfo Graziani, one of Mussolini favorite maschalls. Pariani's reform is frequently used to explain the Italian defeats in WW2, turning all divisions to something unfitted for a long fight. In fact, the main issue remained the lack of  motor vehicules, updated tanks, anti-aircraft and antitank weapons because italian industry was unable to produce the required equipments. Removing Pariani's couldn't change the global situation and in early 1940, the Regio Esercito was not ready for war. Field Marshall Pietro Badoglio send a letter to Mussolini on April, 9th 1940 to warn him about the risks of entering in war alongside Germany. He underlined the lack of available artillery, anti-aicraft guns and effective antitank guns as the Army was using the 47/32 AT gun, only effective at close range. A significant amount of equipment had been lost in Ethiopia and Spain. Badoglio estimated that the global efficiency of the army was at 40%.
Creation of the "Guardia alla Frontiera".

The "Guardia alla Frontiera" (G.A.F.), was an Italian Army Border Guard created in 1937 who defended the 1.851 km of northern Italian frontiers with the so-called "Vallo Alpino Occidentale" (487 km with France), "Vallo Alpino Settentrionale" (724 km with Switzerland and 420 km with Austria) and "Vallo Alpino Orientale" (220 km with Yugoslavia).\nIn 1940 the G.A.F. had 21,000 military personnel, deployed in eight commands, 27 sectors and equipped with 7 artillery regiments. It manned 1,000 fortifications, 6,000 machine guns, 1,000 mortars, 100 Cannone da 47/32 M35, and another thousand other heavy, medium and small-caliber guns (from 149 to 75mm). By 10 June 1940 - Italy's entry into the war - the G.A.F. contained 23 sectors, 50,000 men, 28 battalions "Vallo Alpino", 22 battalions of fascist militia.\nDespite the G.A.F. was a body predominantly static type, its dependencies were also made of five light tank companies, equipped with Fiat 3000 that over time, due to their age and lack of spare parts, ended largely abandoned in Sector armories or buried in order to use the turrets as a fort.
Additional troops of the Guardia alla Frontiera – "A.S.I"

In late 1937, the Guardia alla Frontiera extended its forces in Libya to protect the italian colony from attacks initiated from French Tunisia and British Egypt. Two new divisions were created and the key cities of Tobruch and Tripoli also receive some troops and armaments. These troops were later attached to the 5a Armata "Tripolitana" and the 10a Armata "Cirenaica".
Italian occupation of Albania.

Occupation of Albania was led by the "Corpo di Spedizione Oltra Mare Tirana" (OMT) composed of 23a Divisione Fanteria "Murge", Reggimento di Marina "San Marco", 4 Bersaglieri and 1 Granatieri regiments. This corps receive reinforcements and became lately the XXVI Corpo d'Armata, in charge of the occupation. It was under the command of General Alfredo Guzzoni and later, Sebastiano Visconti Prasca. Alongside Regio Esercito's divisions – 3a Divisione Alpina "Julia", 19a Divisione Fanteria da Montagna "Venezia", 23a Divisione Fanteria "Ferrara", newly formed 53a Divisione Fanteria "Arezzo" and 131a Divisione Corazzata "Centauro" – this occupation corps was composed of cavalry, Frontier Guards, Albanian volunteers and Camicie Nere, to face local resistance and potential ennemies like Yougoslavia and Greece. Italy started recruiting troops from Albania for the MVSN but also for the Army...\n\n§RNote for player: Former 19a Divisione Fanteria 'Gavinana' will be removed. You'll have to attach manually "Julia" and "Centauro" divisions to this corps...§B
Start formation of the 101a Divisione Motorizzata "Trieste".

Formation of the 101st Motorized Division "Trieste" started in the mid-1930's, by the convertion of the 8th Infantry Division "Po" into a motorized division. The 8th Infantry Division left in 1935 some of its regiments to form the Motorized Division "Trento" and was converted into a motorized unit, Divisione Motorizzata "Po", composed of the 66º Reggimento Fanteria "Valtellina", 65° Reggimento Fanteria and 21° Reggimento Artiglieria Motorizzata.
Achieve formation of 101a Divisione Motorizzata "Trieste".

The Motorized Division "Po" was upgrade in 1938 and 1939, including some new attached brigades like the 9º Reggimento Bersaglieri and various support units like engineers and anti-tank. On April 4th, the division was renamed 101a  Divisione Motorizzata "Trieste". It was attached to the newly formed Armored Corps (Corpo d'Armata Corazzato), stationed in Piacenza and its commander was Generale Vito Ferroni. \n\nThe division fought in France and Greece and was then send to North Africa were it participated to the major battles of the Desert War. It finally retreat to Tunisia were it surrendered to the Anglo-American forces in May 1943.
Formation of the 102a Divisione Motorizzata "Trento".

102a Divisione Motorizzata "Trento" was created upon the basis of the former 1a Divisione Motorizzata "Trento", stationned in Libya during the Ethiopian war. In August 1936, it was  rapatriated in Italy and some of its regiments were used to create semi-motorized divisions like the 62a Divisione "Marmarica" (Type AS). In January 1939 the Division get its final organisation including the 7° Reggimento Bersaglieri. Generale Luigi Nuvolini was its commander.
At he outbreak of hostilities with the Allies, 102a Divisione "Trento" was attached to the Corpo d'Armata Corazzato (6a Armata del Po), a reserve unit, and did not took part in combat actions. In 1941, the division was sent to Libya, assigned to the XXI Corpo d'Armata in Nort Africa, and settled in Misurata. Then it participated to all the German-Italian operations until its last fight during the Second Battle of El Alamein were the divsion was almost destroyed. On November 4th, 1942, only 200 Bersaglieri from the 7° Reggimento could disengage.

Actions of the Bersaglieri from the 7, 8, 9 and 12° Reggimenti inspired these words to general Rommel: "Il soldato tedesco ha stupito il mondo. Il bersagliere italiano ha stupito il soldato tedesco" (The German soldier has amazed the world, the Italian Bersagliere amazed the German soldier).
Form the 131a Divisione Corazzata "Centauro".

The 131a Divisione Corazzata "Centauro" was set as an armored division in February 1939 and based upon the 1a Brigata Corazzata formed in April 1938. It was attached to the Corpo d'Armata Corazzato and did large scale manoeuvers in the Po Valley during the late 1930's. Division was put under the command of general Giovanni Magli and rapidly sent to Tirana, attached to the XXVI Corpo d'Armata in Albania, in the perspective of a conflict with Greece.\nInitially equiped with the L3/33 and L3/35 tankettes, it received its first M13/40 tanks in December 1940. The divison took part in the Italian-Greek conflict and then in the invasion of Yougoslavia, before being sent back in Italy to be reequiped with better armor in early 1942. Its final destination was North Africa were the division fought successivly in the battles of El Agheila and Kasserine Pass. It surrendered to the allied forces in may 1943 with the fall of Tunisia.
Form the 132a Divisione Corazzata "Ariete".

The 132a Divisione Corazzata "Ariete" was set at the same time of its sister division "Centauro", on the basis of the 2a Brigata Corazzata. It was attached to the Corpo d'Armata Corazzato belonging to the 6a Armata del Po, a strategic reserve unit.\nThe division did not took part in the battle of the Alps againts France and only saw action in the winter 1940-1941 when four of its tank battalions were sent in Africa in two formations: Gruppo Maletti (Battalions I and II) and Brigata Corrazata Speciale (Battalions III and IV). The complete destruction of the 10a Armata forced the Italian High Command to send the whole division "Ariete" in Africa in January 1941 where it fought alongside the Deutsche Afrika Korps. The "Ariete" was destroyed during the battle of El Alamein.\nIts successive commanders were generals Carlo Vecchiarelli, Ettore Baldassarre, Giuseppe de Stefanis and Francesco Antonio Arena.
Form the 133a Divisione Corazzata "Littorio".

The 133a Divisione Corazzata "Littorio" was the third armored division of the italian forces during the war. It was created in Parma on November 6th, 1939 in Parma on the basis of the former volunteers division "Littorio" sent to the Spanish Civil War so that's why it kept its fascist-inspired name. It was a reserve unit during the invasion of France when it attacked through the Little St Bernard Pass, which was halted by the French defenders.\nIt then took part in the Invasion of Yugoslavia, fighting at Mostar and Trebinje. It was reequipped and sent to North Africa in the spring of 1942 where it fought until it was destroyed at the Second battle of El Alamein in November 1942. Its commander was general Gervasio Bitossi.
Form the Comando Superiore dell'Africa Settentrionale Italiana.

The Comando Superiore FF. AA. "Africa Settentrionale Italiana" was created in april 1937 to take the command of all the italian forces in Libya, replacing the former "Regio Corpo Truppe Coloniali della Libia". 2 armies were transfered under its command: the 5a Armata "Tripolitana" and the 10a Armata "Cirenaica", respectivly covering the Tunisian and Egyptian borders. Air Mashall Italo Balbo was its commander before being killed accidentaly in june 1940 and be replaced by Field Marshall Rodolfo Graziani.
Form the XX Corpo d'Armata.

Already existing during WW1, the italian XX Corpo d'Armata was reconstruct on May 9th of 1937 in Tripoli to be a mobile ("autotrasportabile") unit commanding the two semi-motorized divisions created in the previous month, the 60a Divisione Fanteria autotrasportabile "Sabratha" and the 61a Divisione Fanteria autotrasportabile "Sirte".
This corps received later the semi-motorized 17a Divisione "Pavia" and was appoint to the 5a Armata "Tripolitana". In June 1940, its commander was Ferdinando Cona.

§RNote for player: You will receive this HQ unit already set up but the 2 semi-motorized divisions will be placed in the production queue.§B
Form the XXI Corpo d'Armata.

The XXI Corpo d'Armata was an italian "autotrasportabile" corps created in Bengasi in october 1937 to command two semi-motorized divisions: the 62a Divisione Fanteria autotrasportabile "Marmarica", created in may and the 63a Divisione Fanteria autotrasportabile "Cirene", also formed in october 1937.
This corps successivly took command of other divisions: 1a Divisione Libica, 64a Divisione "Catanzaro", 2ª Divisione CC.NN. "28 ottobre" and the Raggupamento libico “Maletti”. At the begining of the war, the XXI Corpo d’Armata was under the command of general Lorenzo Dalmazzo and attached to the 10a Armata. It suffered heavy losses against the british troops in the battle of Sidi Barrani and was almost destroyed in December 1940.

§RNote for player: You will receive this HQ unit already set up but the 2 semi-motorized divisions will be placed in the production queue.§B
Form the 7a Division Fanteria "Lupi di Toscana".

7a Divisione "Lupi di Toscana" ("Wolfes of Tuscany") was formed in Brescia in december 1937 as a binary division with addition of Camicie Nere brigade. The unit was command by General Edmondo Rossi and assigned to the 1a Armata in 1939, as a reserve division. It briefly took part in the occupation of Albania before fighting in the short campaign against France in june 1940.\nThe division then was involved in the invasion of Greece were it suffered heavy losses in landing in ennemy  without support weapons. The 15th Greek Infantry Division found a new nickname for its opponents: "Hares of Tuscany". Returning back in Italy in 1942, the unit served for coastal defence and participate to the Vichy State occupation in november 1942. It finally surrender to german troops in september 1943.
Form the 9a Armata.

9a Armata – former "Fronte Macedonia" – was an army created on November 9th, 1940 in Pogradec. Its command was given to general Alessandro Pirzio Biroli and the unit was asigned to the Comando FF.AA. "Albania". It took over the operations of the XXVI Army Corps, already in the area of the High Devoli, and the III Army Corps coming from the Italy.
The two units take on a defensive line in the northern sector of the Greek-Albanian border, between Lake Presba and Erseke.

§RNote for player: You will have to attach manualy III Corpo d'Armata and XXVI Corpo d'Armata to this army.§B
Form the 11a Armata.

11a Armata – former "Fronte Epiro" was constituted on November 9th, 1940 in Albania by the transformation of the pre-existing High Command of the Troops of Albania and frames the VIII Corps of the Army and the XXV Army Corps (former Corps of Army Ciamuria). Also from November 9, the Army was destined to the Greek-Albanian border, in the southern sector. Its commander was General Carlo Geloso.\n\n§RNote for player: You will have to attach manualy VIII Corpo d'Armata and XXV Corpo d'Armata to this army.§B
Form the Corpo d'Armata Corazzato.

The "Corpo d'Armata Corazzato" (Armored Corps) was cretaed on November, 11th 1938 in Mantova to receive motorized units of the Regio Esercito: motorized divisions "Po" and "Trento" – becoming later 101a Divisione Motorizzata "Trieste" and 102a Divisione Motorizzata "Trento" – and the I and II Brigate corazzate.\nIn november 1939, these two armored brigades served forming the bulk of two new armored divisions transfered to this corps: the "Ariete" and "Littorio" divisions. Commanded by general Fidenzio Dall'Ora, the Corpo d'Armata Corazzato was attached to the 6a Armata del Po.\nIn 1941, this command unit was rename XVII Corpo d'Armata.
Form the XIV Corpo d'Armata.

The XIV Corpo d'Armata was created on January 1st, 1939 to assume the command of the 32a Divisione Fanteria "Marche" and the 38a Divisione Fanteria "Puglie". It was attached later to the 8a Armata. Its commander was general Giovanni Vecchi. On 10th of June 1940, the corps was located in Venezia but didn't participate in war actions. In February 1941, XIV Corpo d'Armata was transfered to Albania and located in Durazzo and Tirana.
Form the XV Corpo d'Armata.

The XV Corpo d'Armata was created on March 25th, 1939 and attached to the 1a Armata italiana on the Western Front. This unit was under the command of general Gastone Gambara and was set to participate to offensive operations against France.
Many units were attached to this corps:
§R- 5a Divisione Fanteria "Cosseria"
- 37a Divisione Fanteria "Modena"
- 44a Divisione Fanteria "Cremona"
- 15o Comando Guardia alla Frontiera.§B
Form the Corpo d'Armata Autotrasportabile.

The "Corpo d'Armata Autotrasportabile" was a mobile unit attached to the 6a Armata del Po and fit to command "autotrasportabile" infantry divisions. It was stationned in Vicenza at the outbreak of hostilities, under the leadership of general Francesco Zingales.
It participate to the invasion of Yougoslavia and was engaged in July 1941 in the war against Russia, renamed "Corpo Spedizione Italiano in Russia" (CSIR), and finally XXXV Corpo d'Armata – belonging to the 8a Armata – in July 1942.
 Three divisions were attached to this corps:
§R- 9a Divisione Fanteria autotrasportabile "Pasubio"
- 10a Divisione Fanteria autotrasportabile "Piave"
- 52a Divisione Fanteria autotrasportabile"Torino"§B
Form the XVI Corpo d'Armata.

Created in March 1940, the XVI Corpo d'Armata was only assigned defensive task in the area of Milano before being assigned to the defense of Napoli in late 1941. It was in command of several divisions:
§R- 26a Divisione Fanteria da montagna "Assietta"
- 54a Divisione Fanteria "Napoli"
- 206a Divisione Costiera
- 213a Divisione Costiera
- XVIII Brigata Costiera
- XIX Brigata Costiera§B
Its generals were successivly Antero Canale and Carlo Rossi.
Form the XVII Corpo d'Armata Corazzato.

Formation of the XVII Corpo d'Armata started in 1940 alongside the existing Corpo d'Armata Corazzato which was finally merged into this corps on March 1st, 1941. XVII Corpo d'Armata was first assigned to the coastal defense of Calabria before being sent in Albania in April 1941. Divisions passed under its command were 18a Divisione "Messina", 32a Divisione Fanteria da montagna "Marche", 131a Divisone Corazzata "Centauro". Returning to the homeland, on June 16, XVII Corpo d'Armata assumes responsibility for the territorial defense of Lazio. Its units are organized in sectors of coastal coverage and in mobile groups, in order to protect the region, from the borders of Tuscany to the mouth of the Garigliano river. It was enhanced in 1942 by additionnal troops: 103a Division Fanteria autotrasportabile "Piacenza" and 220a and 222a Divisione Costiera. This Corps was dissolved in september 1943. Its successive commanders were generals Giuseppe Pafundi, Vittorio Sogno, Alberto Barbieri and Giovanni Zanghieri.
Formation of the XVIII Corpo d'Armata.

After being constituted a first time between September 10th, 1939 and July 25th 1940 to assume defensive tasks in the Bolzano-Verona area, the XVIII Corpo d'Armata was rebuilt in July 1941 with elements of the dissolved Corpo d'Armata Alpino. Its commanders were successivly generals Marco Gamaleri, Gabriele Basci, Quirino Armellini and Umberto Spigo. It was assigned to Split in 1942 were it took control of the units deployed in Dalmatia and Croatia, doing cccupation and anti-partisan duties.
§R- 12a Divisione Fanteria "Sassari"
- 15a Divisione Fanteria "Bergamo"
- 151a Divisione Fanteria de occupazione "Perugia"
- Comando Truppe di Zara, becoming in september 1942 158a Divisione Fanteria "Zara"
- 1a Divisione Celere "Eugenio di Savoia" for a few monthes.§B
Formation of the XIX Corpo d'Armata.

XIX Corpo d'Armata was created on March 3rd, 1942 in Bolzano but was quikly transfered south in May to the 7a Armata in Campania to assume coastal defence. Units under its command were:
§R- 9a Divisione Fanteria autotrasportabile "Pasubio"
- 222a Divisione Costiera
- XXXII Brigata Costiera§B
In 1943, this unit was tasked to set up two truck-based divisions: the "Piacenza" and the "Mantova", then transferred, respectively, to the XVIII Corpo d'Armata and the XXXI Corpo d'Armata.
The Corps was finally  dissolved on 11 September in Santa Maria Capua Vetere as a result of the events determined by the armistice.
Formation of the XXII Corpo d'Armata.

XXII Corpo d'Armata Corpo was created on September 15th, 1939 in Tobruk and before the outbreak of hostilities with the Allies assumed the command of the 4a Divisione CC.NN. "3 Gennaio" and the newly formed 64a Divisione "Catanzaro". Encircled and unable to be resupplied, XXII Corpo d'Armata was detroyed in the battle for Tobruk (January 1941).\nIt was then reconstitued in Veneto in 1942. On November 11th, following the Anglo-American landing in French North Africa, the XXII Army Corps overtook the Italian-French armistice line, with the "Taro" Division alone, and established itself in Nice. Later he extended his jurisdiction over a large part of Provence, framing the "Piave" and "Lupi di Toscana" Divisions there. Its successive commanders were generals Umberto Somma, Enrico Pitassi-Manella, Federico Ferrari Orsi and Alfonso Ollearo.
Formation of the XXIII Corpo d'Armata.

XXIII Corpo d'Armata was created in Homs on October 15th, 1939 to command the two first fascist militia divisions:
§R- 1a Divisione CC.NN. "23 Marzo" 
- 2a Divisione CC.NN. "28 Ottobre" 
§BThe Corps, commanded by general Annibale Bergonzoli, was initially put in defense of the  Libyan-Tunisian frontier before being transfered to the Egyptian border, in the Bardia area. After a quick offensive in Egyptian territory, the Corps was wisdrawn to defend Sollum and then Bardia, were it was annihilated in January 1941. The corps was recretaed in 1942 in Trieste to assume defensive tasks.
Formation of the XXIV Corpo d'Armata.

XXIV Corpo d'Armata was reconstituted on March 1st, 1943 in Udine by the transformation of the Alpine Army Corps returning from Russia. In June 1943, it was assigned to the Udine area. Under command of general Licurgo Zannini, it organized the defense of the territory and performs, especially in the upper Val Natisone and Judrio, an intense anti-guerrilla activity against the irredentist rebels and the infiltration of slavic partisans. It was dissolved on 11 September as a result of the events determined by the armistice. Units under the command of the XXIV Corpo d'Armata:
§R- 3a Divisione Alpina "Julia"
- 52a Divisione Fanteria Autotrasportabile "Torino"
- Brigata Alpina di Marcia
- Troops of the XI "Guardia alla Frontiera" sector.§B
Formation of the XXV Corpo d'Armata "Ciamuria".

XXV Corpo d'Armata was created on October 24th, 1940 in Albania and was attached to 11a Armata. Thought to fight in the albanian and greek mountains, various alpine and artillery brigades and battalions were assigned as support.
This corps, under leadership of general Carlo Rossi had command of various other units in 1940-1941 during the conquest of the Balkans. In 1942-1943, the corps was assigned to 9a Armata and tasked with occupation and anti-partisan duties. Its commanders were, after, Rossi, generals Giovanni Vecchi and Umberto Mondino.
Initially, only three divisions were under its command:
§R- 23a Divisione Fanteria "Ferrara" 
- 51a Divisione Fanteria "Siena" 
- 131a Divisione Corazzata "Centauro"§B
Formation of the Corpo d'Armata Speciale.

Formed in Padova in November 1940 by transformation of the former "Corpo d'Armata Celere", Corpo d'Armata Speciale was placed under command of general Giovanni Messe. It arrived in Albania in late december 1940 and was attached to the 11a Armata.
Corpo d'Armata Speciale was disbanded in 1941 to form the "Corpo di Spedizione Italiano in Russia" (C.S.I.R.).
This corps was in charge of three units:
§R- 6a Divisione Fanteria "Cuneo"
- 33a Divisione Fanteria "Acqui"
 - Divisione Alpina Speciale, an ad hoc unit based on elements of the 101a Divisione Motorizzata "Trieste"§B
Formation of the XXX Corpo d'Armata.

Constitution of the XXX Corpo d'Armata started on November 15th, 1940 with the transformation of the "Corpo Armale Celere" into a Special Army Corps Command. It was destined in Albania assuming the command of the coastal sector on the front of the 11a Armata, on the Greek-Albanian border. Various units in transit were affected temporarily under its command:  "Siena", "Acqui", "Trieste" "Cuneo", "Ferrara", "Centauro", "Brennero" and "Lupi di Toscana".\nFrom October 1st, 1941, the XXX Corpo d'Armata is transfered to the 7a Armata
column3: in Campania. It took over the 1a Divisione Fanteria "Superga" and oversees the defense of the port of Naples and the coastal areas of Villa Literno, Salerno, Battipaglia and Sapri.\nIn 1943 the XXX Corpo d'Armata was transfered to Sassari and assigned to the defense of Sardegna.

column2: Formation of the XXXI Corpo d'Armata.

XXXI Corpo d'Armata Command was established on November 15th in Catanzaro, under command of general Mario Priore. It has the 16a Divisione Fanteria "Pistoia" and the XI Brigata Costiera under its command to organize the coastal defense of Calabria, in the Ionian area, from the San Nicola stream to the Riona Ragali, and, in the Tyrrhenian sector, from Foce di Castrocucco to Vallone Condoleo. After having let the "Pistoia" Division, it takes on the 201a Divisione Costiera and 212a Divisione Costiera. In 1943, its was added the 104a Divisione Fanteria "Mantova" as a maneuvering unit, and other Coastal divisions were temporarily assigned under its command. The unit was dissolved in 1944.
Formation of the Corpo d'Armata Motocorazzato.

The Corpo d'Armata Motocorazzato was constituted in Roma on July 25th, 1943 to take command of a bunch of  motorized and armored troops of the Regio Esercito. Its commander was general Giacomo Carboni.
Stationned in the Roma area, the Corpo d'Armata Motocorazzato sustained hard battles at the outcome of the Armistice of Casabile (8 September 1943 ), attempting to defend Rome against the advancing German armed forces, protecting the escape of the King's court with his staff, up to the ceasefire order, issued at 10 am, while the fights that involved the defenders of Porta San Paolo, viale Giotto, via Laurentina and Monterotondo. The declaration of surrender agreed on 10 September was stipulated under the command of Brigadier General Giorgio Carlo Calvi di Bergolo, commander of the "Centauro II", husband of the King's firstborn, who took over from Carboni in the convulsive and confused final phase of the battle.
The surrender provoked the dissolution of the Corps and the delivery of armaments to the Germans: only the "Piave" Division remained in service, with tasks of public order in the city of Rome.

Italian army expansion of 1939.

By consequence of the Ordinamento Pariani, the Italian army increase from 31 to 51 divisions from February to October 1939.
Divisions newly formed were assigned to the various existing corps. Most of them had a limited amont of equipment and were assigned to garrison duties in France and later, Yougoslavia and Greece.

You'll have the choice here to go back to the standard of 3 regiments in each division brigade, that war used by almost every belligerant during WW2.\n\n§RNote for player: this event will unlock the technology that increase brigade size.§B
Formation of the 6a Divisione Alpina "Alpi Graie".

6a Divisione Alpina "Alpi Graie" was set up on November 15th, 1941, upon already existing alpine units coming from the Guardia Alla Frontiera. Its battalions were sent in 1942 in Montenegro for anti-partisan duties before returning to Liguria in 1943.
Formation of the 52a Divisione autotrasportabile "Torino".

52a Divisione autotrasportabile "Torino" was set up in June 1940 just before the outbreak of hostilities with the Allies. Its first commanderer was general Mario Arisio. In 1941, 52a Divisione "Torino" was involved in the invasion of Yougoslavia before being sent in Russia (C.S.I.R.). It suffered heavy losses in winter 1942-1943 and the remnants of the unit (1.600 men) were withdrawn to Gorizia.
Formation of the 64a Divisione autotrasportabile "Catanzaro".

64a Divisione "Catanzaro" was set up in 1939 but rebuild as a semi-motorized division in june 1940 and sent to the 10a Armata "Tripolitana" as a reserve division. Motorization was not complete with only 39 trucks working on a 105 initial dotation. At the beginning of 1941, this division has been destroyed and the italian general staff decided to not rebuild this unit because the controversed behavior of its officers on battlefield.
Formation of the 40a Divisione Fanteria "Cacciatori d'Africa".

40a Divisione "Cacciatori d'Africa" was set up at the end of July 1940 in Africa Orientale Italiana (Ethiopia) as a standard infantry division but with italian recruits already settled in Africa. This unit was uncompletly equipped - one signle group of artillery guns - and fought until the fall of A.O.I in May 1941.
Motorization of the 16a Divisione "Pistoia".

In october 1941, the former infantry division "Pistoia" was set up as a semi-motorized unit. Some of its elements were sent in Athens for garrison duties whereas other parts started to be transfered in North Africa. This division was destroyed in May 1943 in Tunisia.
Formation of the occupation divisions.

In the end of year 1941, Italian general staff started to form "occupation" divisions ("Divisioni di Fanteria di occupazione") numbered from 151 to 159 for security duties in France, Yougoslavia, Greece and Russia. The denomination "di occupazione" was promptly removed for obvious reasons and theses divisions ("Perugia","Picenio","Macerata","Murge","Emilia","Vicenza","Novara","Zara","Veneto") were simply designated as Infantry divisions.
 They had a standard italian infantry division structure with the addition of Carabinieri Reali troops (CC.RR. = military police).

Formation of the "Divisioni Costiere" (Coastal Divisions).

Formation of these defensive divisions started in December 1941 when Italy started to fear an amphibious assault from the allied forces that the standard garrisons made of Fascist militia couldn't repel. A second wave was launched in July 1942 and the last ones were raised in spring 1943. Something like 27 divisions - numbred from 201 to 231 were set up with various compositions. Basically, they grouped from 2 to 4 garrison regiments, manned artillery guns from the Regio Esercito of the Milmart (Milizia Maritima) and were reinforced with AA units of the DICAT.
 When the allied finally landed in Sicily and continental Italy, these divisions didn't proved to be efficient.

Formation of Italian paratroopers.

Italian "Paracadutisti" were trained and formed shortly before the Second World War in Castel Benito, near Tripoli, where the first Military Parachute School was located. The first troops trained were two Libyan battalions, the Libyan Parachute Battalion and the 1st National Libyan Parachute Battalion, of the Royal Corps of Colonial Troops. To these were added the first battalions of Italian army troops and the 1st Carabinieri Parachute Battalion (there were three Carabinieri Parachute Battalions). 1 Battalion Royal Carabinieri paratroopers, formed on July 1, 1940, used in Second World War on the North African front (1941). Later in Italy, the staff at Castel Benito was expanded into the School at Tarquinia and became the first elements of the future Divisione Folgore.
Formation of the 185a Divisione paracadutisti "Folgore".

The Folgore ("thunder" in italian) Division was an elite paratrooper division of the Regio Esercito italiano who participated in the battles of Alamein. Formation of this division started in June 1940 with the constitution of three paratroopers batallions who were progressivly reinforced in 1941 by other paratroopers, artillery and engineers batallions near Taquinia. 1a Divisione Paracadutisti was set up on September, 1st of 1941. The division was intended to be used in Operazione C3/Unternehmen Herkules – the planned Axis invasion of Malta – but was finally sent to North Africa under leadership of general Enrico Frattini under the cover name of 185a Divisione "Cacciatori d'Africa", then renamed 185a Divisione paracadutisti "Folgore" in August 1942. Folgore division participated in the battles of El Alamein and faced attacks from three British divisions (44th  Infantry Division "Home Counties", 50th Infantry Division "Northumbrian", 7th Armoured Division "Desert Rats"), and the 1st Free French Brigade. Italian paratroopers repulsed several tanks and heavy infantry assaults with light automatic weapons. Such actions provocated respect and admiration of their opponants. Division was awarded the Medaglia d'Oro al Valor Militare.\nIn the course of the Second Battle of El Alamein, Folgore Division was completely destroyed and therefore officially disbanded on November 1942.\n§RNote for player: you will receive this unit for free if you choose to attack Malta in 1942.§B
Formation of the 80a Divisione Fanteria "La Spezia".

80a Divisione "La Spezia" was created in 1941 in Pisa to be part of the Operazione C3/Unternehmen Herkules, the Axis planned invasion of Malta. It was an airlanding division almost similar to a standard infantry division without its CC.NN. Battalion. It was then reequiped with field artilley and sent in october 1942 in Tunisia to fight as an infantry unit. It suffered heavy losses in 1943 by british tank attacks and was finally captured and dibanded in May 1943 with the fall of italian Tunisia.\n§RNote for player: you will receive this unit for free if you choose to attack Malta in 1942.§B
Formation of the 184a Divisione paracadutisti "Nembo".

184a Divisione paracadutisti "Nembo" was set up in December 1942 upon the basis of the 185o Rgt. Paracadutisti of Division « Folgore » wich participated in combat actions against yougoslavian partisans in Gorizia in april 1943. Then, this regiment was transfered to the south and fought againts the Allies in Sicily (August 1943) whereas the other regiments were send to defend Sardigna in various tactical groups. After the armistice of September 1943, parts of the "Nembo" Division decided to pursue combat with nazi Germany. There was both a "Raggruppamento paracadutisti 'Nembo'" fighting in the ranks of the RSI and a "185º Reparto Autonomo Paracadutisti 'Nembo'" fighting in the Italian Co-Belligerant Army with the Allies troops in Italy...
Formation of the 183a Divisione "Ciclone".

Formed in April 1943, the 183a Divisione paracadutisti "Ciclone" was the third and last italian paratrooper unit of the war. It was composed of only 4 paratroopers battalions under the command of general Giogio Morigi, defending strategic points in the Apennine Mountains on the road from Florence to Bologna. More than half of the division decided to stay loyal to Germany when the Armistice of Cassibile happened…
Regia Aeronautica in A.O.I.

On February 1st, 1935 was formed in Asmara the "Comando Aeronautica per l'Africa Orientale", an operational HQ of the Regia Aeronautica created for the planned war against Ethiopia. Its first commanderer was Ferruccio Ranza, replaced by Mario Ajmone-Cat in september 1935. This air command built 4 airbases and 10 airfields, receive a total of 450 airplanes, from old INAM Ro 1 recon aircrafts to modern Savoia-Marchetti S.M.81 bomber. The bulk of this for was composed by Caproni Ca. 101, Ca. 111 and Ca. 133 for bombing and transport missions.\n\nMussolini's airforce was used intensivly with complete air superiority against unprepared and unequipped grounds troops – Ethiopian soldiers only had this time a very limited number of Oerlikon light anti-aircraft guns...
Use chemical weapons in Abyssinia.

During the second Abyssinian War (october 1935-may 1936), Mussolini's forces used chemical weapons which were banned by the Genova's Protocole of 1925 in consequence of the WWI ravages. Weapons were stocked in Africa years before war but initially, the Italian command was reluctand to use that kind of weapons, fearing international retaliations. At the end of October 1935, Mussolini authorized Rudolfo Graziani to use combat gas as a "utimate weapons" against heavy resistance. Two monthes later, Mussolini finally authorised Marchall Badoglio to use gas in large scale.
In early 1936, Italian airforces delivered large drops of combat gas – mainly yperite and mustard gas - against ennemy troops, civilians and Red Cross Hospitals, held by British, Sweden or Belgians.

International protestations started at the League of Nations, based on various foreign observers reports. Italy admitted bombing mistakes against Red Cross Hospitals by justified the chemical weapons use in retaliation for "war crimes" comitted by Ethiopia: mutilations on captured Eritrean Askari and use of Dum-Dum bullets, banned the Hague Convention of 1899, which was a falsification of reality.

Corpo Aereo Italiano

The Corpo Aereo Italiano (CAI) was an air expeditionary force from that participated in the Battle of Britain and the Blitz during the final months of 1940. Mussolini insisted on providing air support to assist Germany during this operation. The CAI was set up on September 10th and arrived in Belgium in separate parts two weeks mater, under the command of air general Rino Corso Fougier. Between October 1940 and January 1941 the CAI fighters flew 454 offensive and 480 defensive sorties, including 113 bomber escort. At his time, bombers were reasigned to new locations.

The CAI achieved limited success during its brief existence, but it was generally hampered by the inadequacy of its equipment. Most of its losses were due to technical and weather issues.

Albanian Volunteers

After annexation of Albania, Italian High Command started the absorbtion of albanian troops into the Italian Army by the Law N°1115 of July, 13th, 1939. Local troops were especilly integrated to the Carabinieri Reali and the Regia Guardia di Finanza but new troops were also recruited by the MVSN and the Regio Esercito.
Albanian Fascist Militia ("Milizia Fascista Albanese" – MFA) was created soon after the invasion, in April 1939. 4 "Legioni" were raised, totalizing 14 CC.NN. battalions. It was initially recruited from Italian colonists in Albania but later, albanian natives were also recruited. They were wearing the standard MVSN equipment but kept as a distinction sign the Qeleshe, traditionnal white felt fez of Albania.

Regio Esercito integrated Albanian troops in its units, like the "Guardia Reale Albanese", an honor battalion that was attached to the 1° Reggimento of the 21a Divisione Fanteria "Granatieri di Sardegna" in November 1939.Auxiliary battalions of Albanian troops were also raised in 1940 to prepare war with Greece but the recruitment plan was not fullfiled. War records were mixed : some units from the former albanian army did well, some were dissolved during the first two monthes of the conflict, due to casualties and desertions.
Light infantry regiments named "Cacciatori d'Albania" were finally set up in 1942 for occupation duties and anti-partisan operations. In these units, officiers were italian and soldiers mostly albanian muslims.
Addis Abeba massacre.

An attempt of assassination of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, occured on February 19th, 1937. Two young Eritreans named Abraha Deboch and Mogus Asgedom throw a handfull of grenades to kill the supreme governor and viceroy of Italian East Africa but only injured him lightly. The italian response was immediate: for two days, security forces were given a "carte blanche" to kill any Ethiopian in the city. Carabinieri, armymen and Blackshirts killed people blindly, using daggers, truncheons, hand grenades, burning native houses with petrol, screaming "Duce! Duce! Duce!" and "Civiltà Italiana" (Italian civilization). Ethiopian intellectual elites were courtmarshalled and sentenced to death and thousands were sent to detention and concentration camps like Nokra or Danane. Recent researches estimate that 19,200 people were killed, 20% of the population of Addis at the time. 
Repression didn't stop in February: in may, italian investigators found that Abraha and Mogus had stayed a while at the Copt monastry of Debra Libanos and that the monks had the knowledge of their plans. Graziani ordered the summarily execution of 297 monks and 23 laymen living there.
This episod in also named "Yekatit 12", date of the Ethiopian calendar, "strage di Addis Abeba" in italian language and "Graziani massacre" in english. It was one of the worst war attrocities committed by the Italian occupation forces and the worst in Ethiopian history.
Graziani's was nicknamed the "Ethiopian Butcher" but was not jugged after war for the crimes he ordered in Ethiopia.
MilMART 1939.

The Milizia Marritima di Artiglieria (MilMART) was a specialized branch of the MVSN, formed in 1935 from the Milizia per la difesa antiaerea territoriale (DICAT). It was raised to operate coastal artillery batteries and defend Italian coasts from invasions. The MilMART was officialy set up in 1939, with its school an comand located in Messina. It absorbed 25,000 men in 1940, grouped in ten legions and four autonome groups. Logistics and armaments were provided by the Regia Marina but troops were recruited on the MSVN standards. The MILMART manned more than 400 hundred guns of various calibers, from the giant 381/40 2 guns armored turrets of Brindisi to smaller ones...
MilMART 1942.

After the defeats in North Africa, an Allied invasion of Italian mainland was obvious. Fascist Italy started to reinforce its coastal garrisons, particulary in Sicily were  6th, 7th and 8th Legions of the MilMART were insuffisant to defend the Island. Some more Battalions of "Camicie Nere Costiera" were raised and put in defense of the main ports and cities: Messina, Agrigento, Ragusa, Trapani and Siracusa.\nThese units fought against the allies in 1943 defending Lampedusa's Island and later, Sicilian coast.
BETASOM

BETASOM (Italian acronym for "Bordeaux Sommergibile") was an Italian submarine base located in Bordeaux during the occupation of France by Nazi Germany forces. Italy send there its "11° Gruppo del Fero Subacqueo Italiano in Atlantico" under the command of Admiral Angelo Parona in order to help Germany in its blocus strategy against England. BETASOM was not placed under German Kriegsmarine command and remained an independant expeditonnary force until 1943.\nNo less than 30 submarines were sent in Bordeaux between 1940 and 1943, mostly during the september to november 1940 period. The garrison force was made of a naval infantry battalion coming from the San Marco Regiment and several batteries of german anti-aicraft guns. The navy force was supported by the french captured liner Amiral de Grasse and the german cargo Usaramo. Todt organisation started the construction of heavy fortifications to protect submarines from british air raids but they were not finished in 1944. Italy send there some of its modernest submarines (built from 1938 to 1940) going through Gibraltar narrows without difficulties. In 1941, some units (Perla, Guglielmotti, Brin, Argo, Velella, Dandolo, Emo, Otaria, Mocenigo, Veniero, Glauco) were retrieved and sent back to the Mediterranean sea to reinforce the Regia Marina.\nOverall, the Italian submarines sank 109 allied merchant ships totalling 601,425 tons, and suffered the loss of 16 boats.

Military planning for the invasion started during the Second Italo-Abyssinian War when the Italian army command identified the seizure of Malta as a perequisite for massive operations in northern Africa. Multiple seaborne assaults were drawn and periodically revised until the meeting between Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini (29th-30th April 1942). The Axis leaders decided to prepare an air and sea combined assault to take Malta.

Italian Battleship "Conte di Cavour" was ordered in the 1910s, achieved in 1915 but was no used in combat during WW1. Its main armament was made of 2 triple and 2 twin 320 mm guns.

Giulio Cesare is launched!

Giulio Cesare was a Conte di Cavour-class battleship, completed in 1914. She remained almost unused during WW1 and began an extensive reconstruction in October 1933 at the Cantieri del Tirreno (Genoa) that lasted until October 1937. Its main armament was the same as Conte di Cavour, but had a slightly slower speed (27 knots).

Vittorio Veneto was the second member of the Littorio-class battleship that served during World War II. The ship was laid down in October 1934, launched in July 1937, and readied for service with the Italian fleet by August 1940. She was named after the Italian victory at Vittorio Veneto during World War I. She was armed with a main battery of nine 381 mm guns in three triple turrets, and could steam at a speed of 30 knots.
Vittorio Veneto is lost!

Littorio was the lead ship of her class of battleship. She was named after the Lictor ("Littorio" in Italian), in ancient times the bearer of the Roman fasces, which was adopted as the symbol of Italian Fascism. Littorio and her sister Vittorio Veneto were built in response to the French battleships Dunkerque and Strasbourg. They were Italy's first modern battleships, and the first 35.000-ton capital ships of any nation to be laid down under the terms of the Washington Naval Treaty. Littorio was laid down in October 1934, launched in August 1937, and completed in May 1940. It was armed with three triple 381 mm gun turrets and could steam at a speed of 30 knots.

Roma was the third Littorio Class battleship, laid down in September 1938 at the "Cantieri Riuniti dell'Adriatico" of Trieste. The ship was achieved in June 1942 but remained largely inactive during WW2, stationned in la Spezia harbour. She was equipped was nine 381/50 mod 1934 guns in three turrets as primary armament and could steam at 31 knots. She was sunk on September 9th, 1943 by german guided bombs while trying to join the allies after Cassibile's Armistice.

Achille Starace 'Colonna Celere'.

Achille Starace (1889-1945) was a hierarch of the Fascist Party - or PNF. Former Bersagliere during WW1, he rapidly became a supporter of Benito Mussolini and became vice-secretary of the Party in 1921. In 1935, Starace was authorized to participate in the Italian invasion of Ethiopia.
He was given the command of a mixed group of Blackshirts and Bersaglieri being assembled in Asmara, totalizing 3000 men and 500 motor vehicules. This truck transportable column prepare to advance over rough tracks to seize Gondar, capital of Beremder Province. "L’uomo pantera" (the panther man) managed to cover 120 km in three days, taking Gondar in the morning of the first of april 1936 and reaching lake Tana only two days later, securing the border with British Sudan.
Starace wrote his achievments in his book, 'La marcia su Gondar della colonna celere' where you can find an extract of the speech he gave to his men :
 "Soldiers, this is the most risky, most difficult and most important venture of the campaign. Don't waste a shot. (...) Britain is a rich country, Italy is a poor country, but the people of poor countries have hard muscles. The only way to explain the action of the English is that they thought they had only to mass a war fleet in the Mediterranean and Premier Mussolini would take off his hat and bow in submission.Instead he reared up like a thoroughbred horse and sent his soldiers into Africa. Viva Il Duce!"
Achille Starace and the ring of fire.

After Ethiopia, Achille Starace came back to Italy to assume its functions: President of the Italian Olympic Comity and... National Secretary of the PNF. Loyal and obedient, he was appointed here despite of its limitated intellectual capacities. When Marshall Balbo qualified him as an idiot, Mussolini answered that an idiot he was, for sure, but some obdedient idiot.\nStarace is specially and more significantly remembered also for a policy of enrollment of the Italian people (either young or not) in fascist party-linked organizations like Opera Balilla, Figli della lupa, Avanguardisti, Giovane fascista and the labour-related Organizzazione del Dopolavoro.\nStarace was a sports fanatic doing hours of sport, particulary equitation, everyday. He is remembered for such unlikely sports stunts as jumping through a fire circle at the Marmi Stadium in 1938 or horse jumping over a saloon car.
Achille Starace's end.

Starace rapidly ended its political career, being mocked by almost everyone in Italy. A "dire jester" for Field Marshall Emilio de Bono, "Harlequin of an equestrian show" for head of Secret Police Arturo Bocchini, Starace became the object of political satire and popular jokes under fascism, especially from students.\nAfter being assigned to the general Staff of the MVSN in 1939, he participated in the desastrous Greek campaign were he was wounded and then evacuated. Mussolini removed him from its command and he was never trusted again by the fascist rulers. He ended captured and executed by the Partisans on April 28th, 1945.
